Genomic Ranges from GFF File

Source: R/makeGRangesFromGFF.R
makeGRangesFromGFF.Rd

The GFF (General Feature Format) format consists of one line per feature, each containing 9 columns of data, plus optional track definition lines. The GTF (General Transfer Format) is identical to GFF version 2.

makeGRangesFromGFF(file, format = c("genes", "transcripts"))

Arguments

file

File path.
format

Output as genes or transcripts.

Value

GRanges.

See also

Other Gene Annotation Functions: annotable, broadClass, convertGenesToSymbols, convertTranscriptsToGenes, convertUCSCBuildToEnsembl, detectOrganism, emptyRanges, hgnc2gene, makeGRangesFromEnsembl, makeGene2symbolFromEnsembl, makeGene2symbolFromGFF, makeTx2geneFromEnsembl, makeTx2geneFromGFF, mgi2gene, panther, stripTranscriptVersions

Examples

file <- "http://basejump.seq.cloud/mmusculus.gtf"

# Genes
invisible(capture.output(
    x <- makeGRangesFromGFF(file, format = "genes")
))
#> Reading mmusculus.gtf
#> Import genomic features from the file as a GRanges object ... 
#> OK
#> Prepare the 'metadata' data frame ... 
#> OK
#> Make the TxDb object ... 
#> OK
#> Standardizing the metadata columns
#> Setting geneBiotype as factor
#> Defining broadClass using: geneName, geneBiotype, seqnames
summary(x)
#> [1] "GRanges object with 17 ranges and 6 metadata columns"

# Transcripts
invisible(capture.output(
    x <- makeGRangesFromGFF(file, format = "transcripts")
))
#> Reading mmusculus.gtf
#> Import genomic features from the file as a GRanges object ... 
#> OK
#> Prepare the 'metadata' data frame ... 
#> OK
#> Make the TxDb object ... 
#> OK
#> Standardizing the metadata columns
#> Setting geneBiotype as factor
#> Setting txBiotype as factor
#> Defining broadClass using: geneName, txBiotype, seqnames
summary(x)
#> [1] "GRanges object with 20 ranges and 12 metadata columns"
